name: Acceptance Criteria - Survey Set out as per contract drawings and specification, capturing pre-construction levels where needed.
Acceptance Criteria - Complete the on site check to identify, locate and protect all services.
Acceptance Criteria - Complete internal Permits as required to complete works including but not limited to: Hot works, concrete saw, lift, confined space, working at height etc.
Acceptance Criteria - Obtain External Permits as required to complete works including but not limited to: Close approach, Worksafe Notice etc.
Acceptance Criteria - Prior to starting works, Ensure that ESCP plan an approved ESCP by counsil is in place and valid
Acceptance Criteria - Prior to starting works, Ensure that the construction drawings are both IFC and the Current Version.
Specification - As per project specification (Stormwater Swales, 3.1.2)
Acceptance Criteria - Sieve analysis NZS 4402 Test 4.2.8.2
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review
Specification - As per project specification (Stormwater Swales, 3.1.3)
Acceptance Criteria - Single size angular stone chip no larger than 9.5mm
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review
Specification - As per project specification (Stormwater Swales, 3.1.5)
Acceptance Criteria - The media must consist of material that has:
○ 5% clean organic compost from a consistent source. The source of clean organic material must have been provided to the Engineer for acceptance prior to supply.
○ Locally sourced topsoil (free of weeds or contamination)
○ No obvious seeds, weeds, any contamination and material > 25mm in nominal diameter
○ < or = to 50% coarse sand from a consistent source to improve permeability and structure.
○ < 5% by volume of particles exceeding 4.75mm nominal diameter.
○ Well graded particle size from 0.075mm through to 4.75mm with no gaps in the grading.
○ Compacted hydraulic conductivity of at least 50mm/hr and nort exceeding 400mm/hr based on the ASTM F1815-069 methodology.
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review

Specification - As per project specification
(Pipeline Supply, 2.4.4)
Acceptance Criteria - Concrete pipes must be reinforced concrete rubber ring jointed pipe complying with AS/NZS 4058.
Specification - As per project specification (Pipeline Supply, 2.4.2)
Acceptance Criteria - PVC-U pipes and fittings for gravity stormwater must be plain wall construction rubber ring jointed and must comply with AS/NZS 1254.
○ All PVC pipes must have factory fitted, composite rings; loose Z type rings must not be used.
○ PVC-U pipe diameters shown on the Drawings are the nominal diameters unless shown otherwise. Pipe classes are to be as shown on the Drawings
Verifying Document - Concrete pipes must be reinforced concrete rubber ring jointed pipe complying with AS/NZS 4058.
Specification - As per project specification (Pipeline Supply, 2.4.3)
Acceptance Criteria - PE & PP pipe must comply with AS/NZS 5065.
Specification - As per project specification (Pipeline Supply, 2.5.1)

Acceptance Criteria - Unless shown otherwise on the Drawings, manholes (and manhole components) must be circular precast reinforced concrete manholes manufactured in accordance with AS/NZS 4058 with cast in base manufactured to NZ5 3109.
Specification - As per project specification (Pipeline Supply, 2.5.2)

Acceptance Criteria - Manhole lids must be precast reinforced concrete manufactured in accordance with NZS 5109 rated heavy duty (HD60) or HN-H0-72 as specified on the Drawings or as required by the local authority
Specification - As per project specification (Pipeline Supply, 2.5.3)

Acceptance Criteria - Manhole lids must be precast reinforced concrete manufactured in accordance with NZS 5109 rated heavy duty (HD60) or HN-H0-72 as specified on the Drawings or as required by the local authority
Specification - As per project specification (Pipeline Supply, 2.6)

Acceptance Criteria - Use precast single or double catchpits manufactured from reinforced concrete complying with NZS 3101 and NZ 3109. Each single catchpit must have minimum internal dimensions of 450 mm by 675 mm.
○ Use grates rated to class D complying with As 3996 with

Specification - As per project specification
(Pipeline Supply, 2.7)

Acceptance Criteria - Unless shown otherwise on the Drawings, subsoil drains must be DN110 perforated corrugated plastic pipe complying with AS 2439.1-2007 Perforated plastics and drainage and effluent pipe and fittings, Part 1: Perforated drainage pipe and associated fittings, and be minimum SN 4
Specification - As per project specification T-WES 00012, Section 4.8
Acceptance Criteria - Do not change the source of supply of materials without written approval from the Engineer - refer Section 2.1
Verifying Document - Approved list Verification / Datasheet
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review
Specification - As per project specification refer T-WES 00013, 2.4
Acceptance Criteria - All fittings shall be of the material, grade, diameter and pressure class shown on the Drawings/specifications and be on the approved material list
Verifying Document - Approved list Verification / Datasheet
Specification - As per project specification refer T-WES 00014, 2.5
Acceptance Criteria - All fittings shall be of the material, grade, diameter and pressure class shown on the Drawings/specifications and be on the approved material list
Verifying Document - Approved list Verification / Datasheet
Specification - As per project specification refer T-WES 00014, 2.6
Acceptance Criteria - All Joints shall be of the material, grade and size shown on the Drawings/specifications and be on the approved material list

Specification - As per project specification
refer T-WES 00014, 2.7
Acceptance Criteria - All surface boxes and covers over buried valves and hydrants must be rated to AS 3996 Class B (footpaths and non-trafficable areas) or Class D (trafficable areas).
○ Use PVC risers and/or or concrete frames as necessary to provide access to the valves or hydrants.

Acceptance Criteria - For flexible pipes, well graded processed AP20 complying with AS/NZS 2566.2 section 54.2. Any proposed alternative bedding material must meet the requirements of AS/NZS 2566.2 section 5.4.2.1 note 3 and may only be used if approved by the Engineer in writing.

○ Where low-fines embedment material is specified on the Drawings, the material must be a graded AP20 with none passing the 2.36 mm sieve size (no fines material) that has the consistency and moisture content suitable for placement without segregation. Screened in-situ materials may be used for embedment
○ Pea metal may not be used
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review

Acceptance Criteria -For concrete pipes, Material with grading limits in accordance with As/NZS 3725 and the CPAA Engineering Guideline Selecting Materials for Bedding Steel Reinforced Concrete Pipe available from the CPAA website.

○ Where low-fines embedment material is specified on the Drawings, the material must be a gradec AP20 with none passing the 2.36 mm sieve size (no fines material) that has the consistency and moisture content suitable for placement without segregation It is expected that screened in-situ materials will be used for embedment. The material used is to have a Compaction Fraction (CF) of 0.1 or less as defined below
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review

Acceptance Criteria - Before construction commences establish the maximum dry density using NZS 4402 Test 4.1.3 New Zealand vibrating hammer compaction test. Submit results to the Engineer one week before importing trench fill material.
Specification - As per project specification (Minor Concrete Works, 2.1)
Acceptance Criteria - Normal concrete with the requirements of NZS 3104 and strength shown on the drawings. Where the strength us not shown, use 25 Mpa normal concrete
Acceptance Criteria - Geotextile to be the grade and standards on the drawings and be on the Approved materials list.
○ Non-Woven Filtration Class 1 and Geotextile Strength Class C

Acceptance Criteria - Ensure the excavation is clear of roots, projections, or obstructions. If overexcavation occurs, bring the bottom back to grade using excavated material, lightly compacting it. Do not leave loose soil. Notify the Engineer if the swale contains low-permeability soils; they will assess and advise on additional excavation if needed.
Frequency - Before instal the drainage media
Specification - As per three water specification Section 3.3.2

Acceptance Criteria - Carefully position drainage media in a clean, excavated area free of contaminants after removing materials. Use the media as embedment around the subsoil pipe, ensuring it is lightly tamped in the bedding zone without mechanical compaction. Avoid placing or lightly compacting drainage media in flooded excavations or saturated in-situ soils.
Specification - As per three water specification Section 3.3.3

Acceptance Criteria - Position subsoil pipes centrally in the drainage media layer per specifications and drawings. Avoid laying pipes in flooded or saturated soils; no filter sleeves for perforated pipes. Install pipes parallel to bedding, avoiding ponded water in the swale. Carefully place a minimum of 50 mm of drainage media around the pipe, using it as embedment material without mechanical compaction.
Verifying Document - Checksheet, Asbuilt and Photo

Specification - As per three water specification 
Section 3.3.4

Acceptance Criteria - Place a 400 mm thick layer of uncompacted sand over the Drainage Media, avoiding compaction with construction equipment. Ensure the subsoil drain is undisturbed, and rake the sand for a level finish.

Specification - As per three water specification 
Section 3.3.5

Acceptance Criteria - Place soil media in a single lift up to 50 mm above the Construction Drawings' finished level for post-construction consolidation. Ensure a smooth, uniform surface, lightly consolidate the soil, and avoid disturbing the subsoil drain. Rectify sediment blinding as directed by the Engineer. Do not exceed 30% moisture content to prevent poor performance. Notify the Engineer for approval; upon acceptance, commence grass sowing within seven days.
Specification - As per grass sowing mix

Acceptance Criteria - Sow an approved bird-repellent coated grass seed mix at 1 kg/30 m² and fertilize with diammonium phosphate at a minimum rate of 1 kg per 50 m². Aim for a 90% grass strike by the end of the Defects Notification Period, promptly fixing any surface depressions.
Verifying Document - Photo, Docket, Mix design
Inspection Type (Visual, other) - Visual Inspection, Document Review
Specification - Double ring infiltrometer Test Method
Acceptance Criteria - Test reslt > 50 mm/hr as per project spec
○ Test to complete as per project's three water specification Section 3.5.1
Verifying Document - Test result, Witness Engineer
Frequency - Two test per stormwater swale
Acceptance Criteria - Subsoil drains shall be constructed to the lines, levels and dimensions shown on the construction drawings and fully comply with the dimesnional and drawing specifications
Verifying Document - Checksheet, Asbuilt and Photo

Acceptance Criteria - The length of open trench shall not exceed the greater of one manhole length or 50m and when offsite this open trench shall be reduced to a maximum length of not more than 10 metres.

Acceptance Criteria - The minimum trench width shall be 300mm wider than the external diameter of the collar of the pipe being laid, providing the haunching metal is compacted under and at the sides of the pipe.
Acceptance Criteria - Complete Scala testing on the trench Subgrade to a depth of 1m every 10m and when the subgrade changes appearance.

Acceptance Criteria - Pipe inverts shall be laid to ±10mm of the design vertical alignment. Pipes shall be individually aligned to grade. Gravity pipes shall not be laid at a negative grade. Pipe alignments shall be positioned horizontally within the greater of 50mm or 5% of the pipe diameter from the location specified.
Acceptance Criteria - Backfill shall be placed and compacted in layers not exceeding 200mm to 95% of MDD.
Frequency - One test every two layers per 50 m
Acceptance Criteria - Structures shall be positioned within 50mm horizontally of the location specified. All structures shall be watertight.
Acceptance Criteria - Complete Scala test on the subgrade underneath each structure to a depth of 1m
Acceptance Criteria - Unless specified otherwise, all catchpits, manholes and other stormwater structures shall be founded on a minimum 75 mm bedding.
Acceptance Criteria - Backfill shall be placed and compacted in layers not exceeding 200mm to 95% of MDD.
Frequency - One test every two layers per manhole

Acceptance Criteria - Drill holes around the intended cut line before removing the section to create pipe penetrations. Ensure that the diameter of the cutout does not exceed 100 mm beyond the outer diameter of the pipe.
Acceptance Criteria - Construct manhole benching and channelling using 25 MPa concrete. Cast and trowel manhole benching to shape, sloping towards the channel at minimum 1:12 with a U2 finish.
Acceptance Criteria - Pipes shall be haunched and surrounded with concrete to a minimum distance of 200mm from the outside of the manhole in accordance with the drawings.
Acceptance Criteria - Pipe ends shall finish approximately 50mm beyond the inside wall and be plastered with cement mortar or encased in benching concrete in accordance with the drawings.
Acceptance Criteria - Provide a method statement for controlling water in trenches or dewatering for the Engineers acceptance five days before construction, including:
– Reasons why the proposed de-watering system has been chosen.
– Proposed location and details of any well points/spears.
– Details of back-up power supplies in case there is a power failure.
– Details of discharging (location(s), volume and flow rate) including environmental controls.
– A risk assessment with respect to dewatering affecting adjacent structures.
– Detrails of how niose standards will be met.
Acceptance Criteria - Pipelines including laterals shall be tested in accordance with one of the following methods as detailed in AS/NZS 2566.2 Section 6.4:
Acceptance Criteria - The Test must be witnessed by the Engineer or their representative. A record of all tests shall be made and forwarded to the Engineer within 24 hours of test completion.
(b) Full description of section of pipeline being tested, including pipe length, pipe diameter, class and manufacture.
(c) Number of sump connections or laterals on the section being tested.
(e) The start time of the test
(f) The pressure at the start time
(g) Time taken to drop pressure by 2 kPa
(h) Minimum and maximum pressure in the test section and water loss over 30 minutes
(i) Whether the pipeline passed the test
(j) The name and signature of the Contractors personnel responsible for the test
(k) The name and signature of the Engineers nominated personnel who witnessed the test

Acceptance Criteria - An ovality test shall be carried out on gravity pipelines in accordance with clause 6.5 of AS/NZS 2566.2 “Buried flexible pipelines – Installation”. The test shall be carried out at least seven days after the pipe surround is laid.

Acceptance Criteria - All completed pipelines (excluding laterals and sump connections) are to be inspected using CCTV after backfilling and leak testing is successfully completed, but prior to final surface restoration.
○ The specific requirements for the CCTV inspection are found within clauses (a) to (f)

Acceptance Criteria - All manholes (new and refurbished) shall be water tested. Manhole watertightness testing must be witnessed by the Engineer or their representative. A record of all tests shall be made and forwarded to the Engineer within 24 hours of test completion.

Acceptance Criteria - Shape the foundation for uniform pipe support and alignment. Alert the Engineer if unsuitable trench floor material and await instructions before proceeding with additional work.
Acceptance Criteria - Refer engineers advise where the foundation fails to meet the design requirments.
Acceptance Criteria - Geotextiles shall fully wrap raft foundations, in accordance with the manufacturer’s specification, where rafts are required.
Acceptance Criteria - Place and compact all filling materials in layers not exceeding 200 mm compacted thickness. For pipe embedment at least 90% of the maximum dry density (MDD)
Frequency - NDM Every 50 m per 200mm of fill
Acceptance Criteria - Lay in straight lines, beginning at the lower end of the line (unless agreed otherwise in writing with the Engineer), and complete each joint before another pipe is laid.
○ Lay all pipe with manufacturing codes and class markings facing upwards.
Acceptance Criteria - Submit the proposed methodology for pipe laying, concrete work, jointing and backfilling to the Engineer and obtain acceptance before starting pipe installation.
Acceptance Criteria - Unreinforced Concrete Thrust Blocks
○ Precast concrete thrust blocks can only be used where approved by the local authority. Arrange for the Engineer to inspect the first completed thrust block.
Verifying Document - Checksheet, concrete test result
Frequency - On the first completed thrust block
Acceptance Criteria - Reinforced Concrete Thrust Walls / Thrust Blocks
○ All thrust wall steel reinforcement must comply with AS/NZS 4671. Have the Engineer inspect the thrust wall reinforcing and puddle pipe arrangement prior to pouring concrete.
Verifying Document - Checksheet, concrete test result
Frequency - On the first completed thrust block
Acceptance Criteria - Complete the flange bolting procedure as per project spec and check sheet
○ Have the Engineer witness the first flanged joint completed on the PE 100 pipeline
Frequency - First flanged joint completed on the PE 100 pipeline
Acceptance Criteria - AP65 backfill shall be compacted in 200mm loose layers to at least 95% of the maximum dry density (MDD) every 50m.
Frequency - NDM Every 50 m per 200mm of fill
Acceptance Criteria - Complete the pressure test in accordance with the project specification and the check sheet for pressure test.
○ The system test Pressure (STP) is 1,000 kPa.
Acceptance Criteria - Before commencing any pressure acceptance test:
○ Give the Engineer at least two working days notice.

○ Provide the Engineer with a detailed work method statement (WMS) with details of how the pressure testing will be carried out at least 10 working days prior to the test, including but not limited to:
○ Proposed equipment to be used, including pump/s, water meters, logging pressure gauge/s, check pressure gauge/s
○ Proposed fill rate, noting the bulk fill must not be greater than the discharge capacity of any air valves and any local authority constraints relating to the supply of water
○ Calibration certificates for meters and pressure gauges
○ Details of qualified personnel who will be carrying out the tests
○ Source/s of water proposed to be used
○ Location of the pressure test rig and the proposed test pressure at that location if the elevation of the test rig is higher than the lowest part of the test section
○ The test lengths proposed that will ensure that no pipes are over pressurised or inadequately tested
○ Health and safety risks and mitigation measures

Acceptance Criteria - A resolution with a remaining free available chlorine (FAC) level ranging from 15 to 20 mg/L (ppm). By the conclusion of the disinfection period, the water expelled from the pipelines should retain a minimum FAC concentration of 5 mg/L.
– Prepare to submit a WMS for disinfection of potable water pipelines to the Engineer for acceptance before commencing disinfection work. The WMS must include (at least) details of:
○ Swabbing all potable water pipes, valves, and other fittings (> DN 63)
○ How the disinfection solution will be introduced with the initial fill water for pressure acceptance testing, if done, Note that this will be at the Contractors risk

○ How the disinfection solution will be prepared and delivered reliably into the pipeline. Include calculations of dosing and flow rates, strength of the proposed liquid or powered form of hypochlorite as well as methods for checking that the required FAC is being achieved
○ How it is proposed to ensure that all watermains, service pipes, valves and fittings will receive nthe disinfection solution
○ How measurement of the FAC during and at the end of the disinfection process will be achieved to ensure that the system has been fully disinfected
○ How the disinfection solution is to be disposed of safely at the end
○ Identified health and safety risks and proposed mitigation measures

Acceptance Criteria - The Contractor shall open the front outside hose tap, if available, before the supply is reinstated to any premises. Wherever possible, the owner shall be notified prior to this work.
Inspection Point: Quality Control Activity - Upon completion of works

Acceptance Criteria - Compile construction records for final submission ensuring defects (NCRs) / Snags / missing records are captured or closed out, all tests have been received and passed, and changes / omissions have been noted.
Inspection Point: Quality Control Activity - Upon completion of works
Acceptance Criteria - Ensure all items have been surveyed and records are assembled for asbuilting
Verifying Document - As built survey record completed
Inspection Point: Quality Control Activity - Upon completion of works
Acceptance Criteria - Create a set of Redline Drawings for Asbuilt creation noting all changes and departures in CAD or Similar
Inspection Point: Quality Control Activity - Upon completion of works
Acceptance Criteria - Update the project Defect, Snag and Punch List Register
5.5 - All QA documentation collated and signed-off
Inspection Point: Quality Control Activity - Upon completion of works
Acceptance Criteria - All signed and closed out
